qas.question: When did the "Centennial Light" begin burning?
How much light does the bulb emit?

answers.text: the equivalent light of a four watt bulb

qas.question: When did the long-lasting bulb in Texas begin continuing illumination?
Where did the Texas bulb begin its life?
What was not accepted by the Guinness Book of World Records?
What was burning almost continuously at a fire station in Claremont, California?
What year did the long-lasting bulb in New York begin continuing illumination?

plausible_answers.text: 40-watt bulb in Texas that has been illuminated since 21 September 1908

qas.question: What was moved to an area art gallery in 1977?

context: The relationships above are valid for only a few percent change of voltage around rated conditions, but they do indicate that a lamp operated at much lower than rated voltage could last for hundreds of times longer than at rated conditions, albeit with greatly reduced light output. The "<b4_0><b5_0><b6_0>Centennial Light<b6_0/><b5_0/><b4_0/>" is a light bulb that is accepted by the Guinness Book of World Records as having been burning almost continuously at a fire station in Livermore, California, since <a0_0>1901<a0_0/>. However, the bulb emits <a1_0>the equivalent light of a four watt bulb<a1_0/>. A similar story can be told of a <b8_0>40-watt bulb in Texas that has been illuminated since <a2_0><b7_0>21 September 1908<b8_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/>. It once resided in <a3_0>an opera house<a3_0/> where notable celebrities stopped to take in its glow, and was moved to an area museum in 1977.
